property.value: Afghan women washing hands before a meal

note.text: In both formal and casual eating situations with your counterparts, you will often be seated on the floor. Traditionally, food is laid out on a tablecloth spread on the floor or ground, and everyone sits cross-legged on cushions. The host might bring a basin of water to pour over guests' hands, which should be washed before eating.

Meals are generally eaten from communal plates. You will probably eat with your hands, as utensils aren't used at these types of meals. As a gesture of hospitality, your hosts may use their hands to serve you from the communal plates. Be sure to use your right hand for eating and passing dishes.

property.name: mediadisplayblurb
property.value: Afghans and Americans gathered at a meal

note.text: Observe the people around you to learn the appropriate way to dine. If you'd like to return the hospitality you're being shown, you can also serve your hosts more food as necessary.

property.name: mediadisplayblurb
property.value: A service member speaking with his host during a meal

note.text: You will be offered all you can eat, and finishing your plate is an indication that you want more. To indicate that you've had enough, leave a small amount of food on your plate. Always compliment the food and thank your host for their hospitality.
